htmlEmbed:
OpenAI's ChatGPT Criticized by News Media for Using Articles to Train BotBloomberg2/16/2023

Major news outlets have begun criticizing OpenAI and its ChatGPT software, saying the lab is using their articles to train its artificial intelligence tool without paying them.

Media, Artificial Intelligence, Software, Jason Conti, Wall Street, Jobs, technologyRead

EST</time></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class=""><p class="Paragraph_text-SqIsdNjh0t0-" data-component="paragraph">Major news outlets have begun criticizing OpenAI and its ChatGPT software, saying the lab is using their articles to train its artificial intelligence tool without paying them.</p><p class="Paragraph_text-SqIsdNjh0t0-" data-component="paragraph">“Anyone who wants to use the work of Wall Street Journal journalists to train artificial intelligence should be properly licensing the rights to do so from Dow Jones,” <!-- -->Jason Conti<!-- -->, general counsel for <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/NWSA:US" target="_blank" class="Link_link-tVkXhPLPofs-" data-component="link">News Corp.</a>’s Dow Jones unit, said in a statement provided to Bloomberg News. readabilityObject.title: OpenAI's ChatGPT Criticized by News Media for Using Articles to Train Bot
readabilityObject.content:
Major news outlets have begun criticizing OpenAI and its ChatGPT software, saying the lab is using their articles to train its artificial intelligence tool without paying them.

“Anyone who wants to use the work of Wall Street Journal journalists to train artificial intelligence should be properly licensing the rights to do so from Dow Jones,” Jason Conti, general counsel for News Corp.’s Dow Jones unit, said in a statement provided to Bloomberg News. “Dow Jones does not have such a deal with OpenAI.”
